newsitem.title: MONACO: MOTOR RACING-SCHUMACHER LEADS ALL THE WAY TO WIN MONACO.
newsitem.headline: MOTOR RACING-SCHUMACHER LEADS ALL THE WAY TO WIN MONACO.

text.p: Twice world champion Michael
Schumacher took the lead in the world drivers' championship on
Sunday with a masterful victory in the Monaco Grand Prix.
The 28-year-old German led from the start in his Ferrari in
a wet race which, as in 1996, reduced the field to only a
handful of runners at the finish.
He romped home 53 seconds ahead of Brazilian Rubens
Barrichello in a Stewart.
Barrichello's fine drive, which earned his team their first
world championship points, put him ahead of Briton Eddie Irvine
in the second Ferrari with last year's winner, Frenchman Olivier
Panis, fourth in a Prost.
Mika Salo of Finland, driving a Tyrrell, was fifth with
Italian Giancarlo Fisichella in a Jordan sixth.
Schumacher's win ended the Italian team's long wait for a
Monaco victory. It was their first win on the streets of the
Mediterranean principality since Gilles Villeneuve triumphed in
1981 and it helped them celebrate the 50th anniversary of the
team this month.
But it was a disastrous race for Williams who have not won
in Monaco since 1983. Both former championship leader Jacques
Villeneuve of Canada and team mate Heinz-Harald Frentzen of
Germany, who started from pole position, failed to finish.
Schumacher's win lifted him to 24 points in the championship
ahead of Villeneuve on 20 while in the constructors' race
Ferrari now lead with 38 to Williams' total of 30.
The win was the 23rd of Schumacher's career and came in his
90th race.
